item.title: Initial NES / 6502 Dev Machine Setup
item.description: I looked for lists online of tools I’ll need to build my Moon Lander game and found the following from FRITZVD. Below is what I’ve got setup so far: VirtualBox VM w/ the minimal install of Ubuntu Mate (Mate is lightweight and runs well in a VM) Default gVim from apt My Vim setup from my kapp-vim repo The NESASM assembler, built from source. Gimp for making graphics. Although I think I’ll be just using white and black for the initial version.

item.title: A bit of 6502 Assembly
item.description: For some time I’ve been thinking about how fun it would be to build a copy of an old Moon Landing game. I recently discovered that there are tools for writing NES roms from 6502 assembly, C, and JavaScript. I’ve got an emulator running on a Raspberry Pi 2 with a SNES controller. I think it would be super fun to build and play a homemade game on it. To that end I’ve gone through Nick Morgan’s Easy 6502 Tutorial and it was a lot of fun.

item.title: Datomic Datalog Rollup
item.description: Recently I’ve been looking at different ways to calculate roll-up aggregations in a tree of data. These calculations can be done with recursive algorithms. Here I show an example in Datomic. The datomic schema. Just three attributes: :o/name, :o/parent, and :o/x (the rollup field). [{:db/ident :o/name :db/valueType :db.type/string :db/cardinality :db.cardinality/one :db/unique :db.unique/value :db/id #db/id[:db.part/db] :db.install/_attribute :db.part/db} {:db/ident :o/parent :db/valueType :db.type/ref :db/cardinality :db.cardinality/one :db/id #db/id[:db.part/db] :db.install/_attribute :db.part/db} {:db/ident :o/x :db/valueType :db.

item.title: Wires DSL w/ Clojure Spec
item.description: A while ago I found Beautiful Racket by Matthew Butterick. As I worked through the tutorials I found myself wanting to try the same thing with Clojure. Here I’m going to show how I implemented the Wires language from Beautiful Racket in Clojure with spec and macros. I think it’s not a bad pattern for building complicated macros in Clojure. In this case the macro will take a program written in the Wires language and produce Clojure code that computes the result.
